newsitem.title: USA: U.S. envoy in effort to revive Israel-PLO talks.
newsitem.headline: U.S. envoy in effort to revive Israel-PLO talks.

text.p: U.S. Middle East envoy Dennis Ross held high-level talks on Thursday in Gaza and Jerusalem on reviving Israel-PLO peace negotiations but appeared to make little headway in his rescue mission.

The issue that plunged the peace process into crisis, Jewish settlement on land claimed by the Palestinians, took centre stage as settlers occupied a newly acquired house in Arab East Jerusalem in a move coinciding with Ross's visit.
Making his second trip to the region in a month, Ross met Palestinian President Yasser Arafat in Gaza and later held talks in Jerusalem with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
"I cannot tell you that I am optimistic," Netanyahu said to reporters before meeting the envoy.
Asked on Israel Television if a resumption of the peace talks was in the offing, Netanyahu's cabinet secretary, Danny Naveh, told Israel Television: "I am sorry to say I still cannot say that is so."

In a brief statement after Netanyahu and Ross met, the Prime Minister's Office said the U.S. envoy "reported on his meeting with Arafat and will continue to move between the sides in order to continue the process of clarifying positions. Tomorrow (Friday), Ross will be with Arafat".

Israel demands Arafat crack down on "terror" before resuming talks, a move which Netanyahu told reporters "would help the peace process". A Moslem militant blew up a Tel Aviv cafe in March, killing himself and three Israeli women.

Arafat spokesman Marwan Kanafani said the Palestinian leader stressed to Ross the need to stop all settlement activity before peace talks could resume. Netanyahu's aide David Bar-Illan said the work would continue.

"There are difficult problems that have to be overcome but we all realise the importance of trying to find ways to move forward," Ross told reporters in Gaza after meeting Arafat. Ross said he would hold talks again with Arafat on Friday.

Israeli-PLO peace negotiations broke down two months ago after Netanyahu gave the final go-ahead to build 6,500 houses for Jews on a West Bank hilltop which Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli and Palestinian officials have played down any expectation of a breakthrough during Ross's mission.

Palestinians have rejected Israel's offer to build housing for East Jerusalem Palestinians and to discuss speeding up talks on building a seaport and opening an airport in Gaza as part of a compromise to revive peace talks.
On Jerusalem's Mount of Olives on Thursday, Jewish settlers moved into a house acquired for a Jewish religious seminary from a church.

"We don't negate the right of Arabs to live in Jerusalem but Jews have a right to live in all of the city," said Chaim Silberstein, the school's director. "As a yeshiva (seminary) we are not political," he told Reuters at the house.

Palestinians, however, viewed the move as a purely political act to strengthen Jewish presence in the mostly Arab part of the city where the Palestinians hope to establish the capital of a future state.
"This is a very dangerous provocation which will raise tensions and the chance and danger of a clash," said Ahmed Tibi, an aide to Arafat. "It is an attempt to Judaise Arab East Jerusalem."
